This may be obvious to anyone who has made blended soups before but is a serious omission for newcomers.\r\n\r\n2) A high-powered blender makes a huge difference in the final texture. After years of getting by with a $15 Oster I bought in college, I finally got a Vitamix. I know not everyone can afford them, but they are worth it. I replaced the thyme with fresh sage since I had it, this worked really well. I also waited until the blending step to add the cream, to avoid the risk of curdling. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/no-bake-pretzel-peanut-butter-bars/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup graham cracker crumbs (about 8 sheets) ($0.38)\n1/2 cup butter ($0.82)\n1 cup peanut butter (+ 2 Tbsp) ($1.38)\n1 cup powdered sugar ($0.07)\n1.5 cups chocolate chips ($1.19)\n25 mini pretzels ($0.10)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. If your graham crackers aren't already in crumb form, use a food processor to blitz them into a fine crumb.\n2. Place the butter and 1 cup of peanut butter in a bowl. Microwave and stir in 30-second intervals, just until they're warm enough to melt together. Stir until evenly combined. (Reserve the last 2 Tbsp peanut butter for later.)\n3. Add the powdered sugar and graham cracker crumbs to the melted peanut butter mixture and stir until evenly combined.\n4. Line an 8\u00d78-inch baking dish with parchment paper making sure some of the paper overhangs on the sides so you can lift the bars out of the dish later. Press the peanut butter mixture into the bottom in an even layer.\n5. Add the chocolate chips and the last 2 Tbsp peanut butter to a bowl. Microwave for 30 seconds, then stir. Continue to microwave and stir in 15 second increments until the chocolate is fully melted and smooth.\n6. Pour the melted chocolate over the peanut butter base in the baking dish and spread it smooth. Add the mini pretzels on top in even rows (I did five rows of five across).\n7. Refrigerate the peanut butter bars for two hours, or until completely set. Once set, lift the bars out of the dish using the parchment paper. Use a sharp knife to cut them into squares between the pretzels. Enjoy immediately, refrigerate for later, or freeze for long term storage.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Make graham cracker crumbs\n0:11 Melt butter and peanut butter together\n0:16 Stir in graham crackers and powdered sugar\n0:21 Press mixture into baking dish\n0:24 Melt chocolate and peanut butter together\n0:36 Pour chocolate onto base\n0:42 Press pretzels into chocolate\n0:48 Refrigerate until solid\n0:51 Slice into squares\n0:55 Enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2021-06-06T18:11:54+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/NN21lnDOEqk/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/NN21lnDOEqk?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NN21lnDOEqk", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["25", "25 1 square"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT135M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup graham cracker crumbs (about 8 sheets) ($0.16)", "1/2 cup butter ($0.99)", "1 cup peanut butter (+ 2 Tbsp) ($1.38)", "1 cup powdered sugar ($0.32)", "1.5 cups chocolate chips ($1.19)", "25  mini pretzels ($0.10)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If your graham crackers aren&#039;t already in crumb form, use a food processor to blitz them into a fine crumb.", "name": "If your graham crackers aren&#039;t already in crumb form, use a food processor to blitz them into a fine crumb.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/no-bake-pretzel-peanut-butter-bars/#wprm-recipe-55304-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the butter and 1 cup of peanut butter in a bowl. I have made theses more than a few times already, and have brought to 2-BBQs this summer so far.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Liz"}, "datePublished": "2022-07-11"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Absolutely amazing! Don&#39;t stir too often as this will prevent the meat from achieving a nice brown, crispy exterior. The flour may coat the bottom of the pot and that is okay, just don&#39;t let it burn.", "name": "Saute", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/instant-pot-beef-stew/#wprm-recipe-111186-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the beef broth into the pot and stir to dissolve the browned bits from the bottom of the pot. I am lucky enough to have a spaetzle maker - Oma visited her relatives ever few years and one year she brought back spaetzle makers for each of us girls. Now I make spaetzle for my kids, though not as often as I should. Growing up, every family gathering included spaetzle right along with all the best southern foods. She never put cheese on the spaetzle though, I think that may be a regional thing, but she did occasionally make liver spaetzle (liverwurst mixed in the batter) and it\u2019s delicious. The recipe for the filling is pretty good--but with the pineapple, I've most often done this recipe with ground pork, which is significantly less expensive than ground beef. I leave out the pineapple if I use ground beef. I'm not a fan of this \"enchilada\" sauce, but like it fine with several alterations. I much prefer masa harina to flour as a thickener--if you don't have it, just add a couple of corn tortillas to the water and blend. I have preferred soaking 4-5 ancho chiles, and using the soaking water to blend for the sauce. Dried chiles are available at most supermarkets and always at Walmart--they cost a bit more than chili powder, but taste really great. The anchos aren't particularly spicy, but if you use them you can skip the cayenne. Add walnuts or even chocolate!Step-by-step photos can be seen below the recipe card.", "datePublished": "2020-05-02T15:48:06+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Yogurt-Banana-Bread-butter-smear.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Yogurt-Banana-Bread-butter-smear-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Yogurt-Banana-Bread-butter-smear-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Yogurt-Banana-Bread-butter-smear-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Yogurt Banana Bread", "description": "This super moist banana bread recipe uses plain yogurt to keep the bread soft and tender with less butter or oil. Add walnuts or even chocolate! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/yogurt-banana-bread/ \n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 cup mashed ripe bananas (about 3 bananas)\n1 cup plain yogurt \n2 large eggs \n1/2 cup sugar \n4 Tbsp butter, melted \n1 tsp vanilla extract \n1.5 cups all-purpose flour \n1 tsp baking powder \n1/2 tsp baking soda \n1/2 tsp salt \n1/4 tsp nutmeg\n1/2 cup chopped walnuts\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Rub a little butter on the inside of a loaf pan to coat the bottom and sides.\n2. Mash the banana well, then add it to a large bowl along with the yogurt, eggs, sugar, melted butter, and vanilla. Whisk these ingredients until they're well combined.\n3. In a separate bowl, stir together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and nutmeg until well combined.\n4. Pour the dry ingredients into the bowl of wet ingredients and stir together just until there is no dry flour left on the bottom of the bowl (a few lumps are okay, just be careful not to over stir). Gently fold in the chopped walnuts.\n5. Pour the batter into the prepared loaf pan, then bake in the preheated 350\u00baF oven for 60 minutes, or until the bread is brown, cracked open on top, and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean (a few moist crumbs are okay, just no raw batter).\n6. After baking, let the banana bread cool in the pan for about 15 minutes. Once it's slightly cooled it will have pulled away from the bread pan slightly. Run a knife along the sides between the bread and pan, then gently turn the loaf out onto a wire rack to finish cooling. Once cool, slice and serve.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTimestamp:\n0:00  Intro\n0:05 Add bananas to a measuring cup and mash well\n0:12 In a bowl add mashed bananas\n0:14 Add yogurt\n0:16 Add sugar\n0:18 Add eggs\n0:20 Add melted butter\n0:22 Add vanilla\n0:24 Mix well\n0:26 In another bowl, add flour\n0:28 Add baking powder\n0:29 Add baking soda\n0:31 Add salt\n0:32 Add nutmeg\n0:35 Mix dry ingredients and wet ingredients together\n0:40 Add walnuts\n0:45 Pour into prepared baking dish\n0:50 Bake at 350 for 60 minutes", "uploadDate": "2020-05-24T19:03:53+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/5wVhlSWmdhg/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/5wVhlSWmdhg?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5wVhlSWmdhg", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["8", "8 thick slices"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT60M", "totalTime": "PT75M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup mashed bananas (ripe, (about 3 bananas) $0.84)", "1 cup plain yogurt ($0.67*)", "2  large eggs ($0.58)", "\u00bd cup granulated sugar ($0.48)", "4 Tbsp butter (melted, $0.40)", "1 tsp vanilla extract ($0.65)", "1\u00bd cups all-purpose flour ($0.27)", "1 tsp baking powder ($0.02)", "\u00bd tsp baking soda ($0.02)", "\u00bd tsp salt ($0.02)", "\u00bc tsp ground nutmeg ($0.02)", "\u00bd cup chopped walnuts ($0.60)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. I also didn\u2019t use all the butter.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mich"}, "datePublished": "2025-09-11"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "1"}, "reviewBody": "Unsalvageably soggy. I recommend omitting the melted butter or reducing the yogurt to \u00be or \u2154 cup.\r\nIf the result is dryer than desired, the slices can be buttered or served with macerated strawberries. A dry loaf is easy to fix. One that is scorched on the outside and underbaked on the inside? Not so much. \r\n\r\nIf writing recipies for public use, please weigh your flour after measuring it by volume and include that weight in the ingredients list. If your 1.5 cups weighs 220 grams and my 1.5 cups weighs 180, we're not going to get anything close to the same result.\r\n\r\nFlour is sold by weight. You can't accurately calculate the value of the flour in a recipe if you're measuring by volume. If budgeting is a concern, I also recommend using oil instead of butter. Butter is many times more expensive than the equivalent amount of neutral-flavored oil, and any off- flavors in the butter will be noticeable in baked goods. If using yogurt, please specify if it should be Greek yogurt or not. Greek yogurt has a lower moisture content than other styles of yogurt. This does not seem like meticulous budgeting to me. All I have to show for my ingredients and time is frustration and a nearly inedible mess. I don't think I be referencing this blog for recipes again.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Ash"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-04"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "1"}, "reviewBody": "Muffin batter and quickbread batter are the same thing. At worst n the loaf might be a bit dry if you go too far. But a dry loaf can be sliced and buttered or served with macerated strawberries, which will taste much better than a scorched, acrid outside and an inside that would have Gordon Ramsey screaming \"it's raw\". I'm so irritated at how poorly this turned out that I don't want to try any of their other recipes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Ash"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-04"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "1"}, "reviewBody": "It's because the batter has too much liquid for the amount of flour. Omitting the butter or reducing the yogurt to \u00be cup or maybe even \u2154 cup should help. The type of yogurt could make a difference as well. Greek yogurt has less moisture but I noticed that the ingredients list doesn't specify anything other than \"plain\" which I assume means \"unflavored.\" I used Greek yogurt and got a good rise, but it was still too wet and collapsed once it was out of the oven.\r\n\r\nIf the first test loaf comes out a bit dry, serving the slices with butter or macerated strawberries should do the trick.\r\n\r\nBasically, the loaf is underbaked because it's too wet. When the batter is fully set, it can't collapse as the gas inside the loaf cools down. If the batter isn't fully baked, the loaf will collapse under its own weight because the hot gas was the only thing hoding it up.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Ash"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-04"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I had to change the recipe a bit since I only had 1 egg and no butter, which I replaced with MCT coconut oil and I used just that 1 egg. Pull the leaves from the stems and add them to a food processor, along with the olive oil, vinegar, garlic, oregano, cumin, red pepper, and salt. Pulse the mixture until smooth. (Or finely mince the parsley, cilantro, and garlic with a knife and stir together with the remaining ingredients.)", "name": "Prepare the chimichurri by washing the parsley and cilantro leaves well, then shaking off as much water as possible. Pull the leaves from the stems and add them to a food processor, along with the olive oil, vinegar, garlic, oregano, cumin, red pepper, and salt. Pulse the mixture until smooth. The zucchini can be added to the salad raw, grilled, or roasted in the oven first. I used a countertop grill to grill the slices, then cut them into quarter rounds after grilling. If roasting in the oven, toss with a little oil, a pinch of salt and pepper, then roast at 400 degrees for about 20 minutes. Let the zucchini cool slightly.", "name": "Slice the zucchini into 1/4 inch thick rounds. The zucchini can be added to the salad raw, grilled, or roasted in the oven first. Once the zucchini and orzo are no longer steaming hot, combine them in a bowl with the tomatoes. Pour about half of the chimichurri over top, and then toss until everything is coated. Add more chimichurri to your liking (I used about 3/4 of the batch). Taste and add salt or pepper to the salad if needed.", "name": "While the zucchini and pasta are cooling, slice the grape tomatoes in half. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/broccoli-cheddar-chicken-salad/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\nTotal Cost: $4.84 recipe / $1.61 serving\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb. fresh broccoli (about 2 cups chopped) ($1.89)\n1 cup chopped cooked chicken* ($1.16)\n2 oz. cheddar, shredded (about \u00bd cup) ($1.00)\n2 green onions, sliced ($0.25)\n1/3 cup ranch dressing ($0.49)\nfreshly cracked pepper to taste ($0.05)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Finely chop the broccoli. It's important that the broccoli pieces be very small. Chop the chicken into small pieces as well.\n2. Add the broccoli, chopped chicken, shredded cheddar, sliced green onions, and ranch dressing to a large bowl. Stir well until everything is evenly coated in dressing. Add freshly cracked pepper to your liking.\n3. Serve as is, stuff into a tortilla or pita for a sandwich, or stuff into a tortilla and toast in a skillet until the inside is melted for a quesadilla. Keep any remaining salad refrigerated for up to 3-4 days.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTimestamp:\n0:00 Intro\n0:08 Finely chop broccoli\n0:12 Slice green onion\n0:15 Shred cheddar cheese\n0:18 Dice cooked chicken\n0:24 Place all ingredients in a bowl\n0:32 Add dressing\n0:34 Stir until combined\n0:39 Add pepper to test", "uploadDate": "2020-07-26T15:39:00+00:00", "duration": "PT58S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/H2-XYmA_v3Q/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/H2-XYmA_v3Q?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H2-XYmA_v3Q", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["3", "3 about 1 cup each"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT15M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb. fresh broccoli (about 2 cups chopped) ($1.89)", "1 cup chopped cooked chicken* ($1.16)", "2 oz. cheddar, shredded (about \u00bd cup)  ($1.00)", "2  green onions, sliced ($0.25)", "1/3 cup ranch dressing ($0.49)", "freshly cracked pepper to taste ($0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Finely chop the broccoli. Then using medium/indirect heat the meat cooked for another 23 minutes - basting twice more in this time.\u00a0 Checked with a meat thermometer and it was perfect.\u00a0 It had a really nice sear and a thick coating of marinade which made the flavor exceptional.\u00a0 Served with a side of Ranch Style Beans with jalapeno slices, a cold beer and questions about how soon before I can make it again.\u00a0 Thanks for the recipe! \u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Mark"}, "datePublished": "2020-04-23"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I have made this 3x, and it's been amazing! This will prevent it from sticking to your hands and make it easier to work with.Once all the dumplings are in the soup, let them simmer for 20 minutes without removing the lid. If the pit clings, carefully cut around it, then slice each half into three pieces and set them aside.", "name": "Prep the peaches", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat the oil in a medium skillet over medium-high heat. Pat the pork chops dry with paper towels and season with salt and pepper.", "name": "Season", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the pan is hot, gently place the pork in the pan. Let the pork cook undisturbed for 3-4 minutes on each side until a golden-brown crust forms. Remove the cooked pork from the skillet and set aside on a plate while you make the sauce.", "name": "Brown the pork", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the heat to medium, add the peaches, cut side down, and cook undisturbed for 2 minutes.", "name": "Cook", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir in the onions and continue cooking for 3 minutes. Then add the garlic to the skillet and cook for 1 minute.", "name": "Combine", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Deglaze the skillet with the chicken broth and let it reduce by half, 2-3 minutes.", "name": "Deglaze", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Next, add brown sugar, balsamic vinegar, and Dijon mustard, and simmer for about 2-3 minutes.", "name": "Simmer", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lastly, turn off the heat, add the butter, and stir until your sauce has thickened, for about 2 minutes.", "name": "Thicken", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return the pork and any juices to the skillet to warm through. Drizzle with balsamic glaze and enjoy!", "name": "Drizzle", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/summer-peach-pork-chops/#wprm-recipe-133241-step-0-9"}], "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": "4", "ratingCount": "1", "reviewCount": "1"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "I hosted a small get together and I made this, it was a big hit! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/cajun-salmon-burgers/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n6 oz. Canned Salmon (boneless, skinless) \n1/4 cup breadcrumbs \n1 large egg \n1 Tbsp mayonnaise \n1/2 tsp coarse ground mustard\n1 green onion, sliced\n\nCAJUN SEASONING\n1/2 tsp smoked paprika \n1/4 tsp oregano \n1/4 tsp thyme\n1/8 tsp garlic powder \n1/8 tsp onion powder \n1 pinch cayenne (or to taste) \n1 pinch freshly cracked pepper \n1/8 tsp salt \n\nFOR COOKING:\n1/2 Tbsp cooking oil \n1/2 Tbsp butter \n\nOPTIONAL FOR SERVING:\n2 buns \n1/4 cup guacamole \n1 cup spring mix \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Drain the canned salmon and add it to a bowl with the breadcrumbs, egg, mayonnaise, mustard, green onion, and Cajun seasoning spices. Stir to combine the ingredients, then refrigerate for 30 minutes to allow time for the spices to blend and the breadcrumbs to absorb moisture.\n2. After 30 minutes, shape the salmon mixture into two patties, about 3-4 inches in diameter each.\n3. Heat the oil and butter over medium heat in a large skillet. Once the butter is melted and begins to foam, add the salmon burgers and cook for 3-5 minutes on each side, or until the burgers are well browned.\n4. To serve, place one burger on each bun, add 2 Tbsp guacamole to each, and top with a small handful of spring mix. Enjoy!\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-05-11T19:25:53+00:00", "duration": "PT57S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/t0GMGybb7KY/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/t0GMGybb7KY?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t0GMGybb7KY", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["2"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT50M", "recipeIngredient": ["6 oz. I would make this again.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Leslie"}, "datePublished": "2025-01-07"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Really lovely and tasty dish, great yield and great flavor!! Really hearty too, and has that sort of comfort-food quality.\r\n\r\nI accidentally got white sweet potatoes instead of the usual orange ones. They took longer to cook than the sort listed in the recipe, but still tasted fantastic!! So if that's what you've got on hand, they do require some extra time to cook-- Step one was the same, maybe with a bit extra time to get the caramelization you're after (judge by color/crust forming). Added the onions/peppers only, let those sit for about 10 minutes as well (until the onions started getting translucent), and THEN stirred in spices and aromatics and the caned tomatoes and covered still on the medium heat!! That way none of the spices could really singe, and everything had a chance to meld together a little bit in the tomato juices while softening the potatoes. Let that sit on a strong simmer for about 12 minutes until fork-tender. Then add the beans and kale same as the rest of step 4 so they don't break down too much while giving the potatoes the extra time they need to soften up.\r\n\r\nHope that helps if you wound up with some firmer potatoes as well :D Thank you for the wonderful recipe!!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Allegra"}, "datePublished": "2024-12-30"}], "recipeCategory": ["Dinner", "Lunch"], FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/salisbury-steak-with-mushroom-gravy/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 yellow onion, divided \n1 lb. ground beef\n1/2 cup breadcrumbs \n1 large egg\n2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce, divided\n1 tsp Italian seasoning\n1/2 tsp salt\n1/4 tsp pepper\n1 Tbsp cooking oil\n8 oz. mushrooms\n2 Tbsp butter \n2 Tbsp all-purpose flour \n1.5 cups beef broth*\nsalt and pepper to taste\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Finely mince about \u00bd cup of the onion and slice the remainder of the onion. The minced onion will go in the ground beef mixture, the rest will be used for the gravy.\n2. Add the ground beef, minced onion, breadcrumbs, egg, 1 Tbsp of the Worcestershire sauce (the remainder will go in the gravy), Italian seasoning, salt, and pepper to a large bowl. Use your hands to mix the ingredients together until they are evenly combined. Divide the mixture into four equal parts, and shape each into a flattened oval.\n3. Add the cooking oil to a large skillet and heat over medium. Once the skillet is hot, add the shaped beef patties and cook for about 5 minutes on each side, or until they are well browned on each side. Transfer the cooked patties to a clean plate.\n4. While the beef patties are cooking, slice the mushrooms. After removing the beef from the skillet, add the sliced mushrooms and the remaining sliced onion along with a pinch of salt and pepper. Continue to cook the mushrooms and onions over medium until they are soft. Allow the moisture released from the onions and mushrooms to help you dissolve any browned bits off the bottom of the skillet as you stir.\n5. Once the mushrooms and onions have softened and most of the moisture has evaporated off the bottom of the skillet, add the butter and flour. Continue to stir and cook for about two minutes. The flour and butter will form a paste and begin to coat the bottom of the skillet.\n6. Add the beef broth and one tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the skillet. Stir to dissolve the flour into the broth, making sure to dissolve any flour that is stuck to the bottom of the skillet. Allow the broth to come up to simmer (still over medium heat), stirring often. Once it reaches a simmer, it will thicken into a gravy.\n7. Once the gravy is simmering, add the beef patties back to the skillet with the broth, mushrooms, and onions. Spoon the gravy over top, and continue to simmer the beef in the gravy for an additional five minutes. Taste the gravy and adjust the salt and pepper to your liking.\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTimestamp:\n0:00 Intro\n0:10 Slice and mince onion\n0:17 Add onion to ground beef\n0:18 Add breadcrumbs and egg\n0:21 Add worcestershire, italian seasoning, salt and pepper\n0:27 Mix with your hands until combined\n0:32 Divide into four parts and shape into oval patties\n0:36 Slice mushrooms\n0:41 Add oil to pan and cook for five minutes each side\n0:58 Remove patties from the pan and set aside\n1:02 Add mushrooms and onions to pan and saute\n1:10 Add butter and flour to pan\n1:17 Add beef broth to pan and simmer\n1:21 Add worcestershire\n1:25 Add patties back to the pan\n1:32 Spoon sauce over patties\n1:36 Serve", "uploadDate": "2020-05-31T13:11:30+00:00", "duration": "PT1M54S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vYoJxDd198I/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/vYoJxDd198I?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vYoJxDd198I", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT40M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  yellow onion, divided ($0.32)", "1 lb. ground beef ($5.15)", "1/2 cup breadcrumbs ($0.13)", "1  large egg ($0.23)", "2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce, divided ($0.05)", "1 tsp Italian seasoning ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp pepper ($0.03)", "1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)", "8 oz. mushrooms ($1.69)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.26)", "2 Tbsp all-purpose flour ($0.02)", "1.5 cups beef broth* ($0.20)", "salt and pepper to taste ($0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Finely mince about \u00bd cup of the onion and slice the remainder of the onion. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs, ingredient substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/baked-chicken-drumsticks/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 tsp smoked paprika ($0.10)\n1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)\n1/4 tsp onion powder ($0.03)\n1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp dried oregano ($0.03)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n1.75 lbs. chicken drumsticks (6 pieces) ($3.42)\n2 Tbsp cooking oil* ($0.32)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 425\u00baF. \n2. Place the chicken drumsticks in a bowl and drizzle the cooking oil over top. Sprinkle the smoked paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, cayenne pepper, oregano, salt, and pepper over the drumsticks, then toss until they're evenly coated in oil and spices.\n3. Place the seasoned drumsticks on a baking sheet with enough space around each so they're not touching. You can line the baking sheet with foil or parchment for easier cleanup, if desired.\n4. Transfer the chicken to the oven and bake for 40 minutes, or until they reach an internal temperature of 175\u00baF, flipping the drumsticks once half-way through. Serve hot.\n\nNOTES\n*You can use your favorite high-heat cooking oil. \n\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Season drumsticks\n0:26 Place drumsticks on baking sheet\n0:33 Bake chicken\n0:42 Serve and enjoy", "uploadDate": "2021-09-19T14:00:11+00:00", "duration": "PT48S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Dk551YwILbE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/Dk551YwILbE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dk551YwILbE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 pieces"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 tsp smoked paprika ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp onion powder ($0.03)", "1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp dried oregano ($0.03)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp black pepper (freshly cracked, $0.02)", "1.75 lbs. chicken drumsticks (6 pieces, $4.23 *)", "2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.32 **)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 425\u00baF. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPrintable recipe here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/thick-rich-pizza-sauce/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n-2 Tbsp olive oil \n-1 clove garlic, minced \n-28 oz. can crushed tomatoes \n-6 oz. can tomato paste \n-1/2 Tbsp sugar \n-3/4 tsp salt \n-1 tsp basil \n-1/2 tsp dried oregano \n-Freshly cracked pepper \n-Pinch crushed red pepper, optional\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the olive oil and garlic to a sauce pot and cook over medium heat for 1-2 minutes, or just until the garlic is soft and fragrant.\n2. Add the crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, sugar, salt, basil, oregano, some freshly cracked pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill), and a pinch of red pepper flakes. Stir to combine.\n3. Cover the pot, allow the pot to come to a simmer, then reduce the heat to low, and let simmer for 15 minutes minimum, or up to 30 minutes (I often let it simmer as I prepare my pizza dough).\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-09-12T15:00:56+00:00", "duration": "PT1M3S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_3Liw_DRWAE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/_3Liw_DRWAE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_3Liw_DRWAE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["3", "3 cups"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil  ($0.44)", "1 clove garlic (minced, $0.04)", "1 28 oz. can crushed tomatoes  ($1.67)", "1 6 oz. can tomato paste ($0.94)", "1/2 Tbsp sugar  ($0.01)", "3/4 tsp salt  ($0.03)", "1 tsp dried basil  ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp dried oregano  ($0.05)", "Freshly cracked black pepper  ($0.08)", "1 pinch crushed red pepper (optional, $0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the olive oil and garlic to a sauce pot and cook over medium heat for 1-2 minutes, or just until the garlic is soft and fragrant.", "name": "Add the olive oil and garlic to a sauce pot and cook over medium heat for 1-2 minutes, or just until the garlic is soft and fragrant.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/thick-rich-pizza-sauce/#wprm-recipe-33082-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, sugar, salt, basil, oregano, some freshly cracked pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill), and a pinch of red pepper flakes. So much flavor, so little effort.\u00a0", "datePublished": "2019-01-23T14:29:37+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Cauliflower-and-Chickpea-Masala-bowl.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Cauliflower-and-Chickpea-Masala-bowl-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Cauliflower-and-Chickpea-Masala-bowl-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Cauliflower-and-Chickpea-Masala-bowl-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Cauliflower and Chickpea Masala", "description": "This super easy, ultra creamy, and heavily spiced Cauliflower and Chickpea Masala will be your new favorite weeknight dinner! So much flavor, so little effort. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE:https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-cauliflower-and-chickpea-masala/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\nMASALA SPICE MIX\n2 Tbsp garam masala \n1/2 tsp cumin \n1/2 tsp turmeric \n1/2 tsp smoked paprika\n1/4 tsp cayenne \n1/2 tsp salt \nFreshly Cracked Pepper \n\nSKILLET INGREDIENTS\n1 yellow onion \n3 cloves garlic \n1/2 Tbsp grated fresh ginger\n2 Tbsp olive oil \n12 oz. frozen cauliflower florets \n1 15oz. can chickpeas, drained \n1 15oz. can tomato sauce* \n1/4 cup water \n1/3 cup heavy cream\nsalt to taste\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. In a small bowl, combine the spices for the masala spice mix (garam masala, cumin, turmeric, smoked paprika, cayenne, salt, and pepper).\n2. Finely dice the onion, mince the garlic, and grate the ginger. Add all three to a large skillet along with the olive oil and saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the onions are soft and translucent (about 3 minutes). Add the spice mix and continue to saut\u00e9 for one more minute.\n3. Add the frozen cauliflower florets to the skillet with the aromatics and spices, and continue to saut\u00e9 for about 5 minutes more, or until the cauliflower have thawed through and are completely coated in spices.\n4. Add the drained chickpeas, tomato sauce, and 1/4 cup water to the skillet. Stir to combine, then allow them to simmer over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally, for about 15 minutes. This will help mellow the acidity of the tomato sauce and allow the spices to blend. If the mixture becomes too dry as it simmers, add a couple more tablespoons of water.\n5. After the sauce has simmered for 15 minutes, turn off the heat and stir in the heavy cream. Give the masala a taste and add salt as needed. Serve in a bowl either over rice or with a piece of bread for dipping.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-02-23T18:07:56+00:00", "duration": "PT1M3S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/dQ5ytwxBkWs/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/dQ5ytwxBkWs?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQ5ytwxBkWs", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 About 1.25 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT40M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp  garam masala ($0.60)", "1/2 tsp cumin ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp  turmeric ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp  smoked paprika ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp cayenne* ($0.02)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "Freshly Cracked Pepper ($0.08)", "1  yellow onion ($0.70)", "3 cloves garlic ($0.12)", "1/2 Tbsp grated fresh ginger ($0.15)", "2 Tbsp  olive oil ($0.44)", "12 oz. frozen cauliflower florets** ($1.28)", "1 15oz. can chickpeas, drained ($0.94)", "1  15oz. can tomato sauce*** ($1.06)", "1/4  cup water ($0.00)", "1/3 cup heavy cream**** ($0.40)", "salt to taste ($0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, combine the spices for the masala spice mix (garam masala, cumin, turmeric, smoked paprika, cayenne, salt, and pepper).", "name": "In a small bowl, combine the spices for the masala spice mix (garam masala, cumin, turmeric, smoked paprika, cayenne, salt, and pepper).", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-cauliflower-and-chickpea-masala/#wprm-recipe-40901-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Finely dice the onion, mince the garlic, and grate the ginger. If the mixture becomes too dry as it simmers, add a couple more tablespoons of water.", "name": "Add the drained chickpeas, tomato sauce, and 1/4 cup water to the skillet. Heat a deep skillet over medium flame, then add the olive oil. Tilt the skillet to coat the surface in oil, then add the chicken thighs. Cook the thighs on both sides until golden brown and cooked through (about 5 minutes each side). Remove the thighs to a cutting board and let rest.", "name": "While the water for the pasta is heating, season both sides of the chicken thighs with a pinch of salt and pepper. Saut\u00e9 the garlic for 1-2 minutes, or just until it is soft and fragrant.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/chicken-broccoli-pasta-lemon-cream-sauce/#wprm-recipe-30441-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the chicken broth to the skillet and stir to dissolve all the browned bits off the bottom of the skillet. Add the heavy cream, about 1 tsp of the lemon zest, and 2 Tbsp of the lemon's juice. Stir to combine, and allow the cream to come up to a gentle simmer. Simmer the sauce for a few minutes, or until it thickens slightly. Taste the sauce and adjust the salt, pepper, or lemon if needed. Season the sauce liberally so the flavors are not diluted once combined with the pasta, broccoli, and chicken.", "name": "Add the chicken broth to the skillet and stir to dissolve all the browned bits off the bottom of the skillet. Add the heavy cream, about 1 tsp of the lemon zest, and 2 Tbsp of the lemon's juice. Stir to combine, and allow the cream to come up to a gentle simmer. Simmer the sauce for a few minutes, or until it thickens slightly. Taste the sauce and adjust the salt, pepper, or lemon if needed. Season the sauce liberally so the flavors are not diluted once combined with the pasta, broccoli, and chicken.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/chicken-broccoli-pasta-lemon-cream-sauce/#wprm-recipe-30441-step-0-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chop the cooked chicken into small pieces, then add it to the cream sauce in the skillet along with the drained pasta and chopped broccoli florets. I used olive oil instead of butter (thinking the butter\u2019s smoothing qualities are more necessary for canned tomatoes, plus I\u2019m trying to avoid saturated fat) and doubled the rest of the ingredients as listed.\r\n\r\nCanned crushed tomatoes are pretty liquid-y, so I wasn\u2019t sure if the chopped tomatoes would release enough liquid. I checked it after an hour on high, and everything was still pretty chunky, so I added about a cup of red wine to loosen things up. After 4 hours, I immersion-blended, added about 3 teaspoons of salt and a bit of extra-virgin olive oil, and all was lovely.  I\u2019ll probably skip the sugar next time - like the butter, I think it\u2019s less necessary with fresh tomatoes than canned. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: http://www.budgetbytes.com/2015/06/one-pot-roasted-red-pepper-pasta/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n 5 cups vegetable broth \n1 lb. Fettuccine \n1 small Vidalia onion \n4 cloves garlic\n1 12 oz. jar roasted red peppers \n1 15 oz. can fire roasted diced tomatoes\n1/2 Tbsp dried basil\n1/4 tsp crushed red pepper (optional) \nFreshly cracked black pepper \n4 oz. cream cheese (optional) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Thinly slice the onion and mince the garlic. Remove the red peppers from the liquid in the jar and then slice them into thin strips.\n2. In a large pot, combine the broth, onion, garlic, red pepper slices, diced tomatoes (with juice), basil, crushed red pepper, and some freshly cracked black pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill). Stir these ingredients to combine. Break the fettuccine in half, then add it to the pot, attempting to submerge the pieces as much as possible.\n3. Place a lid on the pot and turn the heat up to high. As soon as the pot reaches a full boil, give it a quick stir to loosen any pieces that may have stuck to the bottom, return the lid, and turn the heat down to medium-low.\n4. Let the pot simmer on medium low for 10-12 minutes, stirring every couple of minutes to make sure nothing sticks to the bottom. Return the lid as quickly as possible after each stir. After ten minutes, test the pasta to see if it is al dente. Once the pasta is tender, remove it from the heat. (If the pasta becomes too dry before it is tender, simply add a small amount of water and continue to simmer.)\n5. Divide the cream cheese into tablespoon sized pieces, then add them to the pot. Stir the pasta until the cheese melts in and creates a smooth sauce (it will look lumpy at first, just keep stirring). Serve hot.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\n\n(Sorry 'bout the poor audio quality, folks. Versions of this recipe have been around for more than 75 years. The earliest versions I found yesterday were very luxurious with lots of cream and sherry. Every version from the beginning included mushrooms. In the 1950s, cream and wine had been replaced with condensed cream of mushroom soup and more cheese. I remember this from my childhood and young adult years, and from the beginning the recipes included pimento, probably for color and during my early years, also green peas--may have been regional. Kudos to this version for no high sodium canned soup! The cream cheese, which I didn't see in early recipes, makes a delicious and velvety sauce. This crockpot version makes cleanup easy. This recipe is easy to divide, and I made a half recipe with only 1/4 tsp salt in my little crockpot that I use for queso. I did add 2 T diced pimento and 1/3 c frozen peas, at the end as suggested in the recipe. I love blondies, and have fond memories of eating them in years past. I'm lactose intolerant, so I did a bit of researching how to do brown butter, since my vegan butter substitute, Earth Balance, does not brown on its own (it will get brownish, but it won't get aromatic and nutty like real butter). This may sound strange, but I read you can add a bit of soy sauce (I added about a teaspoon) at the end of the butter melting process, and it adds the extra depth and color. I have to say that the flavor tasted weird in the butter, but once it all baked up, it tasted absolutely delicious. That said, I did not get the texture right. I could tell just in the mixing process that my batter was too stiff, and I'm not sure if that was from cooking the butter too long, overmixing, or what. It did not affect the finished product dramatically at all, but a little denser than I could see the pictures here were. Learn how to make classic homemade chili and what you can add to make it your own! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/basic-chili/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\n- 2 Tbsp olive oil\n- 1 yellow onion\n- 2 cloves garlic \n- 1 lb ground beef \n- 15 oz can kidney beans \n- 15 oz can black beans\n- 15 oz can diced tomatoes\n- 6 oz can tomato paste \n- 1 cup water \nCHILI SEASONING\n- 1 Tbsp chili powder\n- 1 tsp ground cumin \n- 1/4 tsp cayenne powder \n- 1/4 tsp garlic powder\n- 1/2 tsp onion powder \n- 1/2 Tbsp brown sugar\n- 1 tsp salt \n- 1/2 tsp Freshly cracked black pepper\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add both to a large pot with the olive oil and cook over medium heat until they are soft and transparent. Add the ground beef and continue to saut\u00e9 until the beef is fully browned.\n2. Drain the beans and add them to the pot along with the diced tomatoes, tomato paste, 1 cup water, and all of the ingredients for the chili seasoning. Stir until well combined. Place a lid on the pot and allow it to simmer over a low flame for at least 30 minutes, stirring occasionally (the flavor gets better the longer it simmers). \n3. I made this as directed with no changes.\r\n\r\nI would like to mention two things that I have learned over the years.  1)  I now use a 12 x 4 inch tealoaf pan.  It holds the same amount as a 9 x 5 inch pan.  2)  Also, after the bread has baked for 30 minutes, I cover the pan with foil and time it for another 15 minutes, then start testing for doneness.    It pretty much steams itself done.  I now can make quick breads with no fear.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kathy R."}, "datePublished": "2025-10-25"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "I was a little worried reading all the negative reviews, but this worked out well for me! Love the bread, it's not overly sweet, smelled delicious, and was very moist! I used 15oz of pureed squash I had previously roasted and stored in the freezer- this might have had more moisture than canned pumpkin. I added some chocolate chips and baked for about 1 hour. I definitely recommend sticking a knife in to be sure it's not still gooey in the middle. And being sure not to over mix the batter. I might try tenting foil after 40 minutes or so next time because it was just a bit tough on the ends. If you want more sweetness, I'd suggest topping your slice with apple butter or apple sauce! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/pizza-melts/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp butter, room temperature ($0.11)\n1 Tbsp grated Parmesan ($0.11)\n1/2 tsp Italian seasoning ($0.05)\n2 slices hearty bread ($0.44)\n1/3 cup shredded mozzarella ($0.19)\n1 Tbsp pizza sauce ($0.06)\n6 slices pepperoni ($0.15)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Stir together the room temperature butter, grated parmesan, and Italian seasoning in a small bowl until evenly combined. Spread the Parmesan butter over one side of each slice of bread.\n2. Flip the bread over so the un-buttered side is facing up. Place half of the shredded mozzarella on one slice of bread. Next, add small dollops of the sauce over top of the cheese, followed by the sliced pepperoni. Finally, add the remaining cheese. Place the second slice of bread on top to close the sandwich, butter side facing out.\n3. Place the sandwich in a skillet and cook over medium-low heat until golden brown on each side and the cheese is melted on the inside. Cut the sandwich in half and serve!\n\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Make Parmesan Herb Butter\n0:11 Coat Bread with Parmesan Herb Butter\n0:18 Flip Bread and Add Pizza Toppings\n0:29 Close Sandwich\n0:31 Cook in Skillet Until Golden Brown\n0:36 Slice and Serve!", "uploadDate": "2021-06-20T16:48:04+00:00", "duration": "PT48S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/M6mZ0GpnR0o/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/M6mZ0GpnR0o?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M6mZ0GpnR0o", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["1"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT15M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 Tbsp butter, room temperature ($0.11)", "1 Tbsp grated Parmesan ($0.11)", "1/2 tsp Italian seasoning ($0.05)", "2 slices hearty bread ($0.44)", "1/3 cup shredded mozzarella ($0.19)", "1 Tbsp pizza sauce ($0.06)", "6 slices pepperoni ($0.15)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir together the room temperature butter, grated parmesan, and Italian seasoning in a small bowl until evenly combined. Adjust the rack in your oven so that the top of the chicken is 4-5 inches below the broiler. Broil on high for about 5 minutes or until the skin is crispy and browned. I made it for dinner tonight, following the recipe to a T, and it was SO delicious! My hubby and I loved it. Here are my thoughts and how I served it:\r\n\r\n- I don't have a good blender or a food processor, but I do have an immersion blender and I was able to make the sauce very easily by dicing up the ginger first, and then blending it in the tall plastic measuring cup that came with my hand blender.\r\n\r\n- I used one jalape\u00f1o pepper and thought the chicken was really tasty and well-seasoned. I left the jalape\u00f1o pieces off when I transferred the chicken to the broiler and served it, but I might leave them in next time for a bit more heat, and might add some salt and pepper to the sauce as well.\r\n\r\n- I loved the pieces of onion and will double the amount next time so there's more to enjoy. \r\n\r\n- To serve, I made white rice, sauteed some sliced plantains in butter with a sprinkle of allspice, and mixed up some bagged coleslaw with homemade dressing. Next time I intend to jazz up the rice (maybe with coconut milk?) and make a sweet &amp; spicy condiment to dress up the plantains a bit more.\r\n\r\n- You could probably use the leftover liquid from the slow cooker to make a bit of gravy while the chicken is broiling! \r\n\r\nI can't wait to make this again and intend on sharing this meal the next time I'm able to go visit my family!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Shannon Chapman"}, "datePublished": "2020-07-26"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I have no idea if I left the previous comment (or if it was just someone else with a great name) but this works super well in the Instant Pot--I added a cup of water and set it for 20 minutes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Julia"}, "datePublished": "2017-08-28"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I've made  this 3 times and my husband loves it.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Roz"}, "datePublished": "2016-12-06"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I made this tonight for supper using drumsticks. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-vegetable-beef-soup/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 yellow onion ($0.32)\n2 cloves garlic ($0.16)\n2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)\n1 lb. ground beef ($6.49)\n1 russet potato (about \u00be lb.) ($0.79)\n1 28oz. can diced tomatoes ($1.19)\n1.5 tsp Italian seasoning ($0.15)\n1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n4 cups beef broth ($0.52)\n2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce ($0.12)\n12 oz. frozen vegetables (corn, carrots, green beans) ($1.00)\nsalt to taste ($0.05)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add the onion and garlic to a soup pot along with the olive oil. Saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the onions are soft and translucent.\n2. Add the ground beef to the pot and continue to saut\u00e9 until the ground beef is cooked through. If using a higher fat content ground beef, you can drain the excess fat, if you prefer.\n3. While the beef is cooking, peel and dice the russet potato into \u00bd-inch cubes.\n4. Add the cubed potatoes, diced tomatoes (with juices), Italian seasoning, pepper, beef broth, and Worcestershire sauce to the pot. Stir to combine.\n5. Turn the heat up to medium-high and allow the soup to come up to a boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to medium-low and let the soup simmer for about 10 minutes, or until the potatoes are fork-tender.\n6. Add the frozen vegetables to the pot and allow the soup to come back up to a simmer. Simmer the vegetables in the soup for about five minutes.\n7. Finally, taste the soup and add salt to help the flavors pop. Start with \u00bd tsp, if desired, and add more until it reaches your desired level.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIME STAMPS \n0:00 Introduction\n0:06 Saut\u00e9 onions and garlic\n0:12 Add ground beef and cook thoroughly\n0:23 Add tomatoes, potatoes, seasonings, and broth and bring to a boil\n0:28 Add frozen vegetables and simmer\n0:32 Salt to taste & ENJOY!", "uploadDate": "2022-08-21T15:00:10+00:00", "duration": "PT42S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/QsePm344uOE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/QsePm344uOE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QsePm344uOE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 1.5 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT50M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  yellow onion ($0.70)", "2 cloves garlic ($0.08)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.22)", "1 lb. ground beef* ($4.98)", "1  russet potato (about \u00be lb.) ($0.71)", "1 28 oz. can diced tomatoes ($1.63)", "1.5 tsp Italian seasoning ($0.15)", "1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.04)", "4 cups beef broth** ($0.52)", "2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce ($0.14)", "12 oz. frozen vegetables (corn, peas, carrots, green beans)*** ($1.08)", "salt to taste ($0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add the onion and garlic to a soup pot along with the olive oil. Saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the onions are soft and translucent.", "name": "Dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add the onion and garlic to a soup pot along with the olive oil. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2014/02/make-soft-boiled-eggs/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large egg, chilled\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add 1 inch of water to a sauce pot, cover, and bring to a boil over high heat.\n2. Once boiling, add an egg (or however many you'd like as long as they are in a single layer in the bottom of the pot), straight from the refrigerator into the pot. Replace the lid and let it continue to boil for exactly six minutes.\n3. After six minutes, remove the egg(s) from the pot and place them in an ice water bath or run under cool water until they are cool enough to handle. This is a great way to cook it! A tip--never husk the corn in the store unless you plan to cook it within hours. No matter how you want to fix it, the husks keep the ears fresher than plastic bags. I also like to use a light sprinkle of Tajin spice mix to season corn. Sold as a \"fruit spice,\" it's light on chili, heavy on lime. Some stores have it in the produce department while others shelve it either with spices or ethnic foods. It's also delicious on watermelon, fresh ripe peaches, grilled chicken, fish or shrimp. Easy to meal prep and totally satisfying!Step-by-step photos can be seen below the recipe card.", "datePublished": "2025-05-29T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Stuffed-Peppers-tray.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Stuffed-Peppers-tray-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Stuffed-Peppers-tray-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/Stuffed-Peppers-tray-480x270.jpg"], "recipeYield": ["4", "4 servings (\u00bd stuffed pepper each)"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT55M", "recipeIngredient": ["2  green bell peppers (halved, $1.72)", "\u00bc tsp salt (divided, $0.01)", "\u00bc tsp freshly cracked black pepper (divided, $0.02)", "1  yellow onion (sliced thin, (mine was just under 1lb) $0.78)", "4 Tbsp butter (divided, $0.53)", "\u00bc cup vegetable oil (divided, $0.20)", "8 oz white mushrooms (sliced thin, $1.98)", "1 tsp garlic powder ($0.06)", "1 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce ($0.15)", "14 oz shaved beef steak ($7.49)", "4 slices Provolone cheese (*, $0.72)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gather ingredients. Preheat oven to 350\u2109.", "name": "Preheat", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/philly-cheesesteak-stuffed-peppers/#wprm-recipe-125045-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Half the bell peppers, remove the seeds, and brush lightly with vegetable oil and a sprinkle of salt and pepper. Bake for 25 minutes, cut side up, to help them soften before filling.**", "name": "Bake", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/philly-cheesesteak-stuffed-peppers/#wprm-recipe-125045-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Julienne (thinly slice) the yellow onion. Melt 2 Tbsp butter and 2 Tbsp vegetable oil in large skillet and cook onions until very soft and beginning to caramelize over medium-high heat, about 10 minutes. Step-by-step photos can be seen below the recipe card.", "datePublished": "2025-08-02T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Macaroni-Salad-Overhead.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Macaroni-Salad-Overhead-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Macaroni-Salad-Overhead-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Macaroni-Salad-Overhead-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Macaroni Salad", "description": "Macaroni Salad is an easy and inexpensive classic for potlucks, summer BBQs, or an easy side dish for dinner. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/macaroni-salad/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n2 hard-boiled eggs ($0.48)\n1/2 red bell pepper ($0.75)\n1/2 red onion ($0.20)\n2 ribs celery ($0.47)\n8 oz. macaroni ($0.67)\nDRESSING\n1 cup mayonnaise ($1.16)\n1 Tbsp Dijon mustard ($0.18)\n1 Tbsp sweet pickle relish ($0.08)\n1 Tbsp red wine vinegar ($0.10)\n1 Tbsp sugar ($0.01)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp freshly cracked pepper ($0.02)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Chop the salad ingredients first, so they're ready to go. Dice the hard-boiled eggs, bell pepper, onion, and celery.\n2. Boil the macaroni until tender, then drain it in a colander. Briefly rinse the pasta with cool water to cool it off.\n3. While the macaroni is boiling, prepare the dressing. Stir together the mayonnaise, Dijon, relish, red wine vinegar, sugar, salt, and pepper.\n4. Combine the cooled and drained macaroni, egg, bell pepper, celery, and onion in a bowl. Pour the dressing over top, then stir until everything is well combined and coated in dressing.\n5. Serve the macaroni salad immediately or refrigerate until ready to eat.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIME STAMPS \n0:00 Introduction\n0:07 Mix ingredients for dressing in a bowl\n0:17 Cook macaroni & drain\n0:18 Add ingredients to cooled macaroni and stir\n0:28 Add dressing and stir\n0:34 COOL AND SERVE", "uploadDate": "2022-06-26T14:00:11+00:00", "duration": "PT47S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/mPHET30XdZI/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/mPHET30XdZI?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mPHET30XdZI", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["8", "8 servings (\u00be cup each)"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["2  hard-boiled eggs ($0.58)", "\u00bd  red bell pepper ($0.75)", "\u00bd  red onion ($0.49)", "2 ribs celery ($0.20)", "8 oz. macaroni (uncooked, $0.56)", "1 cup mayonnaise ($1.16)", "1 Tbsp Dijon mustard ($0.18)", "1 Tbsp sweet pickle relish ($0.08)", "1 Tbsp red wine vinegar ($0.10)", "1 Tbsp granulated sugar ($0.01*)", "\u00bd tsp salt ($0.02)", "\u00bc tsp black pepper (freshly cracked, $0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chop the salad ingredients, so they&#39;re ready to go. It freezes very well!  I can see how it might be a little bland, but we make these changes to it and like the result: \r\nUse fresh swiss chard instead of frozen spinach. Chop up the swiss chard stalks and add them with or just after carrots and celery. Chop or tear up the leaves a bit before adding them when you'd add the spinach. \r\nDouble the beans (optional, does make it pretty bean-y)\r\nUse a little less black pepper (15 cranks?), and this* spice blend:\r\n1/2 tsp dried basil\r\n1 tsp dried oregano\r\n1/2 tsp + a little more smoked paprika\r\n1/2 tsp (regular) paprika\r\n1/2 tsp cumin\r\n1/4 tsp cayenne\r\n1/4 tsp chili powder\r\n*The recipe includes basil, oregano, and smoked paprika; our changes are adding a little more smoked paprika and adding regular paprika, cumin, cayenne, and chili powder. It's easier for me to read the spices in one list - I have it saved in a note on my phone to reference when cooking. \r\n\r\nSometimes we make cornbread to eat with this, since the flavor profile kind of works, but quinoa really expands and leads to there not being enough broth to dip the cornbread in. When we make it with cornbread, we add 1 extra cup of broth (usually just 1 cup of water + 1 tsp better than bouillon).", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "eyup"}, "datePublished": "2022-08-21"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "Made this last night and it was very good. \r\n Didn't have canned tomatoes so I added some tomato paste and used a white bean. Full Recipe Below \ud83d\udc47 \n\nPRINTABLE VERSION HERE:  https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-make-baked-potatoes/ \n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n4 russet potatoes (\u00bd lb. each)\n1 Tbsp cooking oil\n1 pinch salt\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Wash the potatoes well, then dry them with a towel. Use a fork to prick each potato several times.\n2. Drizzle the cooking oil over the potatoes, then use your hands to smear the oil over each potato until it is fully coated. Place the potatoes on a baking sheet (you can line the baking sheet in parchment or foil for easy cleanup, if desired). Season the potatoes with a pinch of salt.\n3. Bake the potatoes in the preheated oven for about 45 minutes, or until the potatoes can be pierced easily with a fork. Total baking time will depend on the size of your potatoes.\n4. Add the jasmine rice, garlic, salt, coconut milk, and water to a sauce pot, then give it all a brief stir. Place a lid on the pot and bring it up to a boil over high heat. As soon as it reaches a full boil, turn the heat down to low and let it simmer for 15 minutes. After simmering for 15 minutes, turn the heat off and let it sit undisturbed, with the lid in place, for 5 minutes. Fluff the rice, and set it aside until ready to serve.", "name": "Begin the coconut rice first. After simmering for 15 minutes, turn the heat off and let it sit undisturbed, with the lid in place, for 5 minutes. Cut the broccoli crown into florets. Add one inch of water to a large pot, place a steaming basket in the pot, then place the broccoli crowns in the basket. Place a lid on the pot, then place it over medium high heat. Allow the water to come up to a boil, and steam the broccoli until it is bright green and tender (about 5 minutes). Remove the broccoli from the heat and set aside until ready to serve.&nbsp;", "name": "While the rice is cooking, prepare the steamed broccoli. Cut the broccoli crown into florets. This may not be a recommended thing to do, but I always use them for something delicious in 3-5 weeks. I do the same thing with chipotle peppers in adobo sauce and they don't last long, either. They are inexpensive and last a couple of weeks in the fridge vs bags of chopped greens that seem to turn to slime in 5-6 days. Another tip--you can always cook those aging greens. Working in batches, add the gyoza with the seam side up, and fry until the bottom is golden brown and crispy. Using the lid as a shield, pour about 1/4 to 1/3 cup water into the skillet and quickly place the lid on top to contain the steam and splatter. Let the gyoza steam in the skillet for 1-2 minutes, or until most of the liquid has boiled away. Remove the lid and let the gyoza cook for a minute more, or until the bottom is crispy again. Usually we use coconut milk to temper a curry with very pungent flavours (such as red curry) but with mild tasting spinach and chickpeas and minimum spice, adding a can of full fat coconut would make it very bland.  So I added more spice including more cumin, added coriander, chili powder, tumeric (when curry powder added), garam masala (at the end), a whole green chili for flavour and cilantro leaves as well. More salt too....and NO coconut milk. The curry came out mild but pleasant without being bland. I think some restaurants that have fried green tomatoes on the menu have gardens--I just have deer, so no joy. Fried green tomatoes, in my life, have always been an end of season treat. You know the one--harvest every tomato in sight before the frost hits and store them spread out on newspapers in a cool dark place where they will slowly ripen. Keep a batch in the freezer for quick weeknight dinners later!", "datePublished": "2025-02-16T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/homemade-meatballs-spoon.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/homemade-meatballs-spoon-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/homemade-meatballs-spoon-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/homemade-meatballs-spoon-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Homemade Meatballs", "description": "These easy homemade meatballs are freezer-friendly and versatile. Keep a batch in the freezer for quick weeknight dinners later! \nFULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/homemade-meatballs/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 cup plain breadcrumbs ($0.32)\n1/2 cup grated Parmesan ($0.88)\n1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)\n1/2 tsp onion powder ($0.05)\n1/2 tsp Italian seasoning ($0.05)\n1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp pepper ($0.03)\n2 large eggs ($0.42)\n1/4 cup whole milk ($0.11)\n1 lb. bulk Italian sausage ($3.00)\n1 lb. ground beef ($5.99)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. In a small bowl, combine the breadcrumbs, Parmesan, garlic powder, onion powder, Italian seasoning, salt, and pepper. In a separate small bowl, lightly whisk the two eggs.\n2. Add the breadcrumb mixture, eggs, milk, Italian sausage, and ground beef to a large bowl. Use your hands to mix the ingredients together until evenly combined. Avoid over mixing the meat.\n3. Let the meatball mixture rest for five minutes to allow the breadcrumbs time to soften. Divide and shape the meat into about 40 meatballs, approximately 2 Tbsp in volume each.\n\nOVEN COOKING INSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Line a baking sheet with parchment. Place the meatballs on the baking sheet about one inch apart from each other.\n2. Bake the meatballs for about 15 minutes, or until lightly browned.\n3. Transfer the meatballs to a pot of red sauce and simmer for five more minutes in the sauce. If not using a red sauce, add an additional 3-5 minutes to the bake time, or until the meatballs are cooked through.\n\nSTOVETOP COOKING INSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add a tablespoon of cooking oil to a large skillet and heat over medium. 2. Once hot, swirl the oil to coat the surface of the skillet. Add half of the meatballs to the skillet.\n3. Cook the meatballs, turning every couple of minutes, until browned on all sides and cooked through. Repeat with the second batch of meatballs.\n4. Transfer the cooked meatballs to a pot of red sauce and simmer for a few minutes more before serving.\n\nFREEZING INSTRUCTIONS\n1. You can freeze the meatballs either cooked or uncooked. I prefer freezing them already cooked so they can go straight from the freezer into a pot of red sauce and then just simmer until heated through. Cooked meatballs should be completely cooled before placing in a gallon-sized freezer bag and transferred to the freezer.\n2. To freeze uncooked meatballs, place the raw meatballs on a parchment-lined baking sheet and freeze on the baking sheet until solid (1-2 hours) before transferring to a gallon-sized freezer bag for longer storage. Thaw completely before cooking.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:06 Season breadcrumbs\n0:17 Whisk eggs\n0:21 Combine meat, breadcrumbs and eggs\n0:34 Shape meatballs \n0:37 Add meatballs to a baking sheet\n0:40 Bake meatballs\n0:43 Add meatballs to sauce and stir\n0:52 Serve and ENJOY!", "uploadDate": "2022-05-15T15:00:11+00:00", "duration": "PT1M2S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/IFc_IuVMXbA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/IFc_IuVMXbA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFc_IuVMXbA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["8", "8 about 4 meatballs each"], "prepTime": "PT25M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT55M", "recipeIngredient": ["\u00bd cup plain breadcrumbs (70g, $0.17*)", "\u00bd cup grated Parmesan (50g, $1.92)", "\u00bd tsp garlic powder ($0.05)", "\u00bd tsp onion powder ($0.05)", "\u00bd tsp Italian seasoning ($0.05)", "\u00bc tsp salt ($0.02)", "\u00bc tsp black pepper (freshly cracked, $0.03)", "2 large eggs ($1.58**)", "\u00bc cup whole milk (4 oz., $0.04)", "1 lb. bulk Italian sausage (454g, $3.57***)", "1 lb. ground beef (454g, $4.98)", "1 small yellow onion ($0.70)", "2  garlic cloves ($0.08)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.44)", "2 Tbsp tomato paste ($0.18)", "28 oz. crushed tomatoes (1 can, $1.67)", "\u00bd tsp dried basil ($0.05)", "\u00bd tsp dried oregano ($0.05)", "1 tsp brown sugar (optional, $0.02)", "1 tsp salt (or to taste, $0.03)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, combine the breadcrumbs, Parmesan, garlic powder, onion powder, Italian seasoning, salt, and pepper. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-rosemary-garlic-white-bean-soup/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\n- 2 Tbsp olive oil \n- 4 cloves garlic \n- 3 15 oz. cans cannellini beans \n- 2 cups vegetable (or chicken) broth\n- 1/2 tsp dried rosemary \n- 1/4 tsp dried thyme \n- 1 pinch crushed red pepper \n- freshly cracked pepper to taste\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n\n1. Before you begin, pour one of the cans of cannellini beans (with its liquid) into a blender and pur\u00e9e until smooth. Drain the other two cans of beans.\n\n2. Mince the garlic and add it to a soup pot with the olive oil. Saut\u00e9 the garlic over medium for about one minute, or just until the garlic is very fragrant.\n\n3. Add the pur\u00e9ed cannellini beans, the other two cans of drained beans, broth, rosemary, thyme, crushed red pepper, and some freshly cracked pepper. Stir to combine.\n\n4. Place a lid on the pot, turn the heat up to medium-high, and bring the soup to a boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to medium low, remove the lid, and allow it to simmer for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally.\n\n5. Smash the beans slightly to thicken the soup even more. Taste the soup and add salt if needed (I did not add any, this will depend on the salt content of your broth). Serve hot, with crusty bread for dipping!\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-11-08T21:47:57+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/pjHY9CPZ-u0/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/pjHY9CPZ-u0?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pjHY9CPZ-u0", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 1.25 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.44)", "4 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "3 15oz. cans cannellini beans ($2.82)", "2 cups  vegetable (or chicken) broth ($0.26)", "1/2 tsp dried rosemary* ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp dried thyme* ($0.02)", "1 pinch crushed red pepper ($0.02)", "freshly cracked black pepper to taste ($0.03)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Before you begin, pour one of the cans of cannellini beans (with its liquid) into a blender and pur\u00e9e until smooth. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/thai-cucumber-salad-2/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/3 cup rice vinegar \n2 Tbsp granulated sugar\n1/2 tsp toasted sesame oil\n1/4 crushed red pepper\n1/2 tsp salt\n2 large cucumbers\n3 green onions\n1/4 cup chopped peanuts\n\n1. In a small bowl, combine the rice vinegar, sugar, sesame oil, crushed red pepper, and salt. Set the dressing aside.\n2. Peel and slice the cucumber using your favorite method (see photos below for my technique). Place the sliced cucumbers in a large bowl.\n3. Chop the peanuts into smaller pieces. Slice the green onions.\n4. Add the peanuts, green onions, and dressing to the sliced cucumbers. Stir to combine. Serve immediately or refrigerate until ready to eat. A few notes:\r\nMaybe it's just my crockpot temp, but if I put the green onions in at the beginning, they go to ugly mush, no flavor or texture. I do a fine chop and add them as a fresh garnish at the end (or skip entirely)\r\nI've had some issues with getting the juice to thicken from broth to sauce. I use whatever cut of beef is on sale, and they all cook down a little differently. If I add the cornstarch-and-cold-water directly to the crock pot, it's hit and miss whether the broth will thicken at all. Better to separate out the broth to a skillet, bring to a simmer, add the corn starch-and-cold-water, and instant thick sauce! \r\nI also use bragg's amino acids instead of soy sauce - I'm gluten intolerant, and most soy sauce brands have some wheat. The amino acids give the same soy flavor, but slightly less salty.\r\nSide recommendations: rice is a must, and I like adding green peas or the oven roasted frozen broccoli on the side.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Rachel"}, "datePublished": "2024-09-29"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Delicious! Also, I cooked it for 8 hours on low and there was no need for the corn starch because there was no juice left over, which was just fine with me. I liked it, I ate it, and I will continue to eat the leftovers over the next couple days... BUT, Next time I make it, I will use 1/3C of soy sauce and 1/3C of water instead of 1/2C of soy sauce. I might add a bit more brown sugar, too, because I like things a bit sweet. In addition, I used very lean stew beef and missed the fat so I'll use a fattier cut of meat next time.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Isabelle"}, "datePublished": "2022-09-07"}], I made a few changes to the recipe you might want to consider: \r\n-replaced 2 TBSP of brown sugar with an extra 1/2 cup of mashed banana (same sweetness, more fiber)\r\n-swapped 1/4 tsp of nutmeg for 1/4 tsp of cinnamon (I love cinnamon in baked goods) \r\n-reduced shredded coconut to 1/4 cup (I love the added punch of coconut flavor, but I'm not as keen on the texture)\r\n-used quick oats in place of rolled oats (I prefer a smoother texture) \r\n-reduced amount of oats to 2 cups (quick oats tend to absorb liquid more quickly) \r\n-baked in an 8x8 baking pan in an oven set to 375 for 35 minutes (compared to my previous attempt at 45 minutes, reducing the baking time locked-in more moisture)\r\nThe final product is luscious, creamy baked oatmeal\u2014like banana bread that keeps you full past breakfast and holds up to a spoon. The long, overnight fermentation develops the gluten with no effort from you!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2012-04-02T20:15:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/FocacciaRollsclose.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/FocacciaRollsclose-500x480.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/FocacciaRollsclose-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/FocacciaRollsclose-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Focaccia Rolls", "description": "These are the easiest and most delicious dinner rolls with a wonderfully crispy crust. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2012/04/focaccia-rolls/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n4 cups all-purpose flour \n1/2 Tbsp salt \n1/4 tsp instant yeast \n2 cups water \n2 Tbsp olive oil \n2 Tbsp Italian seasoning\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. The day before (about 18 hours ahead of time) combine the flour, salt, and yeast in a large bowl. \n2. Stir until well mixed. Add the water, starting with 1.5 cups, and add a little more at a time until the flour forms a cohesive, wet ball. There should not be any dry flour left on the bottom of the bowl. The total amount of water you\u2019ll need will vary, but should be between 1.5 to 2 cups. See the photos below for more info.\n3. Loosely cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let it sit at room temperature for 16-18 hours to ferment.\n4. After 16-18 hours, the dough will look like a large, bubbly mass. Sprinkle with enough flour to be able to scrape it out of the bowl without it sticking to your hands. Place the dough on a well floured surface. Cut the dough into 12 pieces. Shape each piece into a small ball. The dough will be quite wet, floppy, and sticky, so sprinkle liberally with flour as you work.\n5. Place the rolls on a baking sheet covered in foil and lightly sprayed with non-stick spray (I used two baking sheets). Brush the top of each lightly with olive oil. Sprinkle the Italian seasoning over top. Let rise for 30 minutes to one hour or until doubled in size.\n6. While the rolls are still rising, preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Once it is fully preheated, place the rolls in the oven and bake until the surface is a light golden brown (about 25 minutes). Serve warm!\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-01-17T14:01:33+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/APR8FzHMhzU/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/APR8FzHMhzU?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=APR8FzHMhzU", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["12"], "prepTime": "PT1080M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT1105M", "recipeIngredient": ["4 cups all-purpose flour  ($0.59)", "1/2 Tbsp salt  ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp instant yeast  ($0.02)", "2 cups water  ($0.00)", "2 Tbsp olive oil  ($0.24)", "2 Tbsp Italian seasoning  ($0.30)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The day before (about 18 hours ahead of time) combine the flour, salt, and yeast in a large bowl.
