I believe the author intended to say 2 1/4 tsp, which is the amount in one packet.\r\nI have made this with one packet and it is excellent.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Diane"}, "datePublished": "2024-09-23"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Can I ferment this in the fridge for 72 hours to develop flavor?", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Janet"}, "datePublished": "2023-03-14"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "Made this recipe twice. The first time the bottom got really hard as I was waiting for the top to get light golden brown as the recipe states. Was very unsatisfied, but when warming up in microwave on damp paper towel, they got softer and were still pretty good in soup. It was pretty flavorless though.\r\nThe second time, I doubled the salt since I was using a courser salt than table salt, I put a heaping tablespoon of italian seasoning inside the dough rather than only putting on top, and I only left it in for about 28 minutes when the bread was still pretty pale. It was amazing! I ate five that day because I couldn't stop myself. Only thing I'm going to change next time from how I made it the second time is to go with 3/4 T salt rather than 1 T salt. It's a pity that the bread doesn't actually come out like the pretty picture, but it tastes amazing and is especially good for dipping in soups so I'm definitely going to make more of this in the future. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/chocolate-depression-cake/ \n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\nCHOCOLATE CAKE\n1.5 cups all-purpose flour\n1 cup granulated sugar\n1/2 tsp salt\n1 tsp baking soda\n1/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder \n1/3 cup cooking oil\n1 Tbsp vinegar \n1 tsp vanilla extract \n1 cup water \n\nCHOCOLATE ICING (optional)\n1.5 cups powdered sugar \n1/4 cup cocoa powder \n3 Tbsp water\n1 tsp vanilla extract \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n\nCHOCOLATE CAKE\n1. Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. In a large bowl, stir together the flour, sugar, salt, baking soda, and cocoa powder until well combined.\n2. Add 1 cup water to a liquid measuring cup, then add the vanilla extract and vinegar to the water.\n3. Add the oil to the bowl of dry ingredients, followed by the water mixture. Stir until the chocolate cake batter is mostly smooth. Make sure no dry flour remains on the bottom of the bowl.\n4. Pour the cake batter into an 8x8\" or 9x9\" baking dish. Transfer the baking dish to the oven and bake the cake for 35 minutes.\n\nCHOCOLATE ICING\n1. If using the chocolate icing, let the cake cool for at least an hour after baking before adding the icing.\n2. Wait until the cake is cool, then prepare the icing. Add the powdered sugar, cocoa powder, and vanilla extract to a bowl. Begin adding water, 1 tablespoon at a time, until it forms a thick but pourable icing (about 3 Tbsp total). If you let the icing sit, it may begin to dry, but you can add a splash more water to make it moist again.\n3. Pour the icing over the cooled cake and spread until the cake is evenly covered. Slice the cake into 9 pieces and serve.\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTimestamp:\n0:00 Intro\n0:04 Egg Free Dairy Free Chocolate Cake\n0:10 In a bowl combine flour, sugar, salt, baking soda and cocoa power until well combined\n0:17 Combine water, vinegar and vanilla.\n0:20 Add wet ingredients to dry ingredients\n0:22 Add oil\n0:24 Stir until just combined\n0:27 Pour into prepared pan\n0:30 Bake at 350 for 35 minutes\n0:37 Let cool\n0:38 Prepare frosting\n0:39 In a bowl combine powdered sugar, cocoa powder, vanilla and water. \n0:46 Stir until combined\n0:50 Pour frosting atop cake\n0:56 Slice and serve!", "uploadDate": "2020-06-27T18:16:19+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/LOFgPvZchEE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/LOFgPvZchEE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LOFgPvZchEE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["9", "9 1 slice each"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT110M", "recipeIngredient": ["1.5 cups all-purpose flour ($0.27)", "1 cup granulated sugar ($0.96)", "\u00bd tsp salt ($0.02)", "1 tsp baking soda ($0.02)", "\u2153 cup unsweetened cocoa powder ($0.57)", "\u2153 cup cooking oil ($0.21*)", "1 Tbsp vinegar ($0.06**)", "1 tsp vanilla extract ($0.65)", "1 cup water ($0.00)", "1.5 cups powdered sugar ($0.48)", "\u00bc cup unsweetened cocoa powder ($0.42)", "3 Tbsp water ($0.00)", "1 tsp vanilla extract ($0.65)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Chocolate Cake", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Mexican Chorizo  ($1.67)", "4  boneless skinless chicken thighs about 1 1/4 lbs. ($2.35)", "12 oz. bag frozen onion, bell pepper, celery mix ($1.39)", "2 Tbsp tomato paste  ($0.12)", "2 1/2 cups dry long grain white rice  ($0.83)", "1 15 oz.  can diced tomatoes  ($0.89)", "4 cups chicken broth ($0.52)", "1  whole bay leaf  ($0.15)", "1 tsp cumin  ($0.10)", "1 tsp smoked paprika  ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp oregano  ($0.05)", "1  bunch green onions  ($0.79)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the chicken thighs into small, one inch chunks. Add the vegetable oil to a large pot along with the chopped chicken thighs and chorizo (squeeze the chorizo out of the casing). Cook the meat over medium heat until the chorizo is browned and the chicken is white and firm (about 7-10 minutes). Drain off the excess fat. Add the frozen, chopped onion, celery, and bell pepper mix. Stir to combine and heat through (about 1-2 minutes).", "name": "Cut the chicken thighs into small, one inch chunks. Add the vegetable oil to a large pot along with the chopped chicken thighs and chorizo (squeeze the chorizo out of the casing). Cook the meat over medium heat until the chorizo is browned and the chicken is white and firm (about 7-10 minutes). Drain off the excess fat. Add the frozen, chopped onion, celery, and bell pepper mix. Stir to combine and heat through (about 1-2 minutes).", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/chorizo-chicken-jambalaya/#wprm-recipe-31865-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the tomato paste and dry rice to the pot. Stir to combine and dissolve anything stuck to the bottom of the pot. Finally, add the bay leaf, cumin, smoked paprika, and oregano. Stir once more, place a lid on the pot, and turn the heat up to high. As soon as the pot reaches a full boil, turn the heat down to low and let it simmer for 30 minutes. After 30 minutes, turn the heat off and let the pot sit for an additional 10 minutes, undisturbed, to continue to steam.", "name": "Add the chicken broth and diced tomatoes (with juices) to the pot. Microwave on high for 30 seconds, then stir until the butter is dissolved. Add an additional 10 seconds if needed. You want the milk warm enough to melt the butter, but not scalding.", "name": "While waiting for the yeast, combine the milk, butter, and the rest of the sugar in a measuring cup or microwave safe bowl. Microwave on high for 30 seconds, then stir until the butter is dissolved. Add an additional 10 seconds if needed. You want the milk warm enough to melt the butter, but not scalding.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/english-muffins/#wprm-recipe-33563-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the yeast is foamy, pour the milk and butter mixture into the bowl, along with 1 cup of the flour, and the salt. Stir until the mixture is mostly smooth. Add the second cup of flour, about 1/3 cup at a time, stirring to combine each time. Finally, begin to add the third cup of flour, 1/3 cup at a time, until you can no longer stir it with a spoon. At that point, turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for about 5 minutes, dusting with small amounts of flour as you go. Once finished kneading, you should have used 2.5-3 cups flour total.", "name": "Once the yeast is foamy, pour the milk and butter mixture into the bowl, along with 1 cup of the flour, and the salt. Stir until the mixture is mostly smooth. Add the second cup of flour, about 1/3 cup at a time, stirring to combine each time. Finally, begin to add the third cup of flour, 1/3 cup at a time, until you can no longer stir it with a spoon. At that point, turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for about 5 minutes, dusting with small amounts of flour as you go. Once finished kneading, you should have used 2.5-3 cups flour total.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/english-muffins/#wprm-recipe-33563-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the dough rest for 15 minutes, then roll it out to about 1/2-inch thickness. Use a cookie cutter or sharp edged drinking glass to cut several discs out of the rolled dough. Cut them as close to each other as possible to leave few scraps. When you can cut no more circles, ball the scrap dough up, flatten it once again, and cut a few more. Place the cut muffins on a baking sheet coated with a liberal layer of cornmeal.", "name": "Let the dough rest for 15 minutes, then roll it out to about 1/2-inch thickness. Use a cookie cutter or sharp edged drinking glass to cut several discs out of the rolled dough. Cut them as close to each other as possible to leave few scraps. When you can cut no more circles, ball the scrap dough up, flatten it once again, and cut a few more. Place the cut muffins on a baking sheet coated with a liberal layer of cornmeal.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/english-muffins/#wprm-recipe-33563-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the muffins rise in a warm moist area for about 1.5 hours, or until they are slightly more than double the size. (I placed a casserole dish full of steaming water on the bottom rack of my oven and placed the baking sheet on the top rack to keep the muffins moist as they rose.)", "name": "Let the muffins rise in a warm moist area for about 1.5 hours, or until they are slightly more than double the size. (I placed a casserole dish full of steaming water on the bottom rack of my oven and placed the baking sheet on the top rack to keep the muffins moist as they rose.)", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/english-muffins/#wprm-recipe-33563-step-0-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the muffins are large and fluffy, it's time to cook them in a skillet. Heat a cast-iron or non-stick skillet over medium low heat. Once the skillet is preheated, carefully use a spatula to lift 3-4 muffins from the baking sheet and slide them into the skillet, along with some cornmeal. Let the muffins cook 3-4 minutes, or until lightly golden brown on the bottom. Carefully flip the muffins and cook for 3-4 minutes on the second side. The muffins will puff further as they cook in the skillet. Once the muffins are golden on both sides and sound hollow when tapped, transfer them to a wire rack to cool.", "name": "When the muffins are large and fluffy, it's time to cook them in a skillet. Heat a cast-iron or non-stick skillet over medium low heat. Once the skillet is preheated, carefully use a spatula to lift 3-4 muffins from the baking sheet and slide them into the skillet, along with some cornmeal. Let the muffins cook 3-4 minutes, or until lightly golden brown on the bottom. Carefully flip the muffins and cook for 3-4 minutes on the second side. The muffins will puff further as they cook in the skillet. Once the muffins are golden on both sides and sound hollow when tapped, transfer them to a wire rack to cool.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/english-muffins/#wprm-recipe-33563-step-0-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once completely cool, split the muffins with a fork and toast in a toaster or the oven. It's so hard to let it simmer my mouth can't wait to taste", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jacko"}, "datePublished": "2020-08-11"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I'm going to give this 5 preemptive stars because I know what the finished product will taste like: delicious. \r\n\r\nPuttanesca has been a family go-to favorite of our for decades. When nothing else tastes appealing....\r\n\r\nBut THREE anchovy fillets? That's all? C'mon, Beth! Use at least half the tin if not the entire thing. If you're going to go briny go BIG! :-)", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "The Pontificator"}, "datePublished": "2020-03-09"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Your origin of why this sauce is called Puttanesca is spot on and I wanted to include what someone said on a thread who is from Rome to further confirm the history behind the name:\r\n\"\r\nI'am from Rome Italy - where there is an entire neighborhood called after a \"relatively\" famous prostitute, apparently favored by the 1%ers of the time - . While recipes for Pasta alla Puttanesca vary slightly, my comment has more to do with the origin of the name of this special - and delicious - sauce.  It is called that way because it includes the only ingredients that would be available to a \"Puttana\" of the time, in order for her to prepare a midnight little meal for her patron, after their night of frolics - and yes there was only one patron per night for a reputable, \"supported\" mistress (we are not talking about brothels here, where meals for clients were not offered) - so... no attracting clients by the way of the appealing smell. It only includes items that were shelf-stable, preserved pantry essentials, and nothing fresh at all (which is understandable, considering that the \"Puttane\" of the time were not allowed to leave the house during the day and go to the market to get fresh produce and ingredients). I am sure that there will be people who disagree with this explanation. Unfortunately, the sauce is Italian and this is the Italian popular cultural meaning attached to it.\"", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "kazy"}, "datePublished": "2019-11-11"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Leaving a review because I saw it only got 3 votes so far! I add cheese, sometimes a little cream, parsley and sometimes zucchini or whatever veg I have on hand", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "katrina"}, "datePublished": "2019-09-04"}], FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-oven-baked-fish-with-tomatoes/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n \n1 15 oz. can fire roasted diced tomatoes \n2 cloves garlic, minced \n2 Tbsp olive oil \n1/2 tsp dried oregano \n1/4 tsp salt \nfreshly cracked pepper\n1/2 Tbsp lemon juice \n1 lb. white fish (four 4oz. fillets)\nchopped fresh parsley for garnish (optional) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Drain the excess liquid from the can of diced tomatoes. Combine the diced tomatoes in a bowl with the garlic, olive oil, oregano, salt, some freshly cracked pepper (about 10 cranks of a pepper mill), and lemon juice. \n2. Spread about 1/3 of the tomato mixture in the bottom of a casserole dish big enough to fit all of your fillets without overlapping. Lay the fish fillets over the tomato mixture, then spoon the rest of the tomatoes over top, completely covering the fish.\n3. Bake the fish for about 15 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 145\u00ba and the fish easily flakes. Serve hot, with a sprinkle of chopped fresh parsley on top.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-09-08T17:33:49+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/plPEvygeF0A/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/plPEvygeF0A?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=plPEvygeF0A", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 15 oz. can fire roasted diced tomatoes ($1.00)", "2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.23)", "1/2 tsp dried oregano ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)", "freshly cracked pepper ($0.03)", "1/2 Tbsp lemon juice ($0.06)", "1 lb. white fish (four 4oz. fillets) ($4.95)", "chopped fresh parsley for garnish (optional) ($0.11)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Place one chicken breast at a time in a heavy-duty freezer bag (unsealed) and use a tenderizing mallet (or a rolling pin\u2026 whatever is safe and sturdy that you have on hand) to hammer each one 1/4&quot; thin, starting in the thicker middle part of the breasts and working your way to the ends. Repeat this process until all breast pieces are 1/4&quot; thick and equally flat.", "name": "Cut", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/chicken-marsala/#wprm-recipe-91906-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine \u00bd tsp salt, black pepper, dried Italian herb seasoning, and all-purpose flour in a shallow bowl, reserving 1 Tbsp of flour. Scrape the bottom of your pan with a wooden spoon as you go; the browned bits on the bottom become a tasty part of your sauce!", "name": "Saut\u00e9", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/chicken-marsala/#wprm-recipe-91906-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the Marsala wine and broth to the pan, scraping the browned bits off the bottom again. Then, whisk in the flour \u201cslurry\u201d, minced parsley, and butter until it has completely melted. Finally, add the chicken cutlets back, flipping them halfway, cooking for another 4 minutes total. It baked evenly, rose nicely and relatively uniformly, has good, spicy flavour (though not particularly lemon-y without the glaze), and has a good texture. I don't think I'd guess it was eggless or only had 1 tablespoon oil if someone baked this for me; the texture was lighter than I anticipated!\r\n\r\nThe more nitpicky stuff for the recipe tinkers:\r\n- I used 1/2 cup whole wheat flour and 1 cup AP; I halved the sugar (1/2 cup sugar total)\r\n- I reduced the ground ginger to 1/2 tsp, added 1/4 tsp ground cardamon, and used 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice in place of ground nutmeg\r\n- I used 1 tablespoon lemon juice from my lemon instead of vinegar; I also added 1 tsp vanilla to that well\r\n- I baked in a convection oven at ~325F for 25 minutes in a 8x8 glass pan\r\n\r\nThank you to Diana for the recipe, and thank you, Beth, for getting permission to make this post and share this!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2018/01/pork-peanut-dragon-noodles/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\nDRAGON SAUCE\n1/4 cup chili garlic sauce \n1/4 cup soy sauce \n1/4 cup brown sugar \nPORK AND NOODLES\n1/2 lb. ground pork* \n6 oz. ramen noodles \n3 green onions, sliced \n1/4 cup unsalted peanuts, chopped \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Combine the chili garlic sauce, soy sauce, and brown sugar in a bowl.\n2. Add the ground pork to a skillet and cook over medium heat until it is fully browned*. Once browned, add the prepared dragon sauce and chopped peanuts. Allow the pork and peanuts to simmer in the sauce for another 5 minutes, or until the sauce has reduced by half.\n3. While the pork is browning, begin boiling water for your noodles. Once boiling, add your noodles and cook according to the package directions. Drain the noodles in a colander.\n4. Once the sauce has reduced and the noodles have drained, add the noodles to the skillet and toss until everything is combined and coated in sauce. Top with sliced green onions and serve!\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-03-24T20:49:35+00:00", "duration": "PT1M3S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/FdmIIK_Ny4A/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/FdmIIK_Ny4A?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FdmIIK_Ny4A", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["3"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup chili garlic sauce ($0.53)", "1/4 cup soy sauce ($0.24)", "1/4 cup brown sugar ($0.16)", "1/2 lb. ground pork* ($1.50)", "2 3oz. packages ramen noodles (seasoning packets discarded) ($1.00)", "3  green onions, sliced ($0.20)", "1/4 cup unsalted peanuts, chopped ($0.12)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the chili garlic sauce, soy sauce, and brown sugar in a bowl.", "name": "Combine the chili garlic sauce, soy sauce, and brown sugar in a bowl.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pork-peanut-dragon-noodles/#wprm-recipe-35818-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the ground pork to a skillet and cook over medium heat until it is fully browned*. It&#39;s delicious, vibrant, easy, and versatile!", "datePublished": "2023-05-17T11:22:50+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/Yuca-en-Escabeche-spoon.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/Yuca-en-Escabeche-spoon-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/Yuca-en-Escabeche-spoon-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/Yuca-en-Escabeche-spoon-480x270.jpg"], "recipeYield": ["8", "8 cups"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT70M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb yuca (fresh or frozen) ($1.55)", "4 tsp kosher salt, divided ($0.16)", "2/3 cup olive oil  ($0.84)", "1/3 cup distilled white vinegar ($0.41)", "3  bay leaves ($0.30)", "1/2 tsp black peppercorns ($0.05)", "1 tsp adobo seasoning ($0.04)", "1  yellow onion, sliced in half moons ($0.42)", "8 cloves garlic, thinly sliced ($0.34)", "1/4 cup sliced Spanish olives (AKA Manzanilla olives ) ($0.33)", "1/8 cup olive brine ($0.09)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If the yuca is fresh, peel and split it into 4-inch long quarters. "https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ba1bd0462fb679d2843531eee7ec6006d9d8bd5e121185288552dd38fcf68b6a?s=96&d=mm&r=g", "caption": "Beth Moncel"}, "description": "I\u2019m a food lover, number cruncher, Making great food is my passion, my purpose, and my favorite thing to share with others.", "sameAs": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/about/", "https://www.facebook.com/budgetbytes1", "https://x.com/Budget_Bytes"], "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/author/beth/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Louisiana Style Red Beans and Rice with Sausage", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Beth Moncel"}, "description": "Classic Louisiana style red beans and rice are a naturally budget friendly meal that will give you leftovers for days! Freezer friendly!", "datePublished": "2025-03-13T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Louisiana-Red-Beans-and-Rice-Fork.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Louisiana-Red-Beans-and-Rice-Fork-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Louisiana-Red-Beans-and-Rice-Fork-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Louisiana-Red-Beans-and-Rice-Fork-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Louisiana Red Beans and Rice", "description": "Classic Louisiana style red beans and rice are a naturally budget friendly meal that will give you leftovers for days! Freezer friendly! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/louisiana-red-beans-rice/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb. dry red beans ($1.49)\n2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)\n14 oz. Andouille sausage ($3.79)\n1 yellow onion ($0.32)\n1 green bell pepper ($0.69)\n3 ribs celery ($0.46)\n4 cloves garlic ($0.32)\n2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.20)\n1 tsp dried oregano ($0.10)\n1 tsp dried thyme ($0.10)\n1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)\n1/2 tsp onion powder ($0.05)\n1/4 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.03)\n1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n2 bay leaves ($0.60)\n6 cups water ($0.00)\n1/4 cup chopped parsley ($0.20)\n1 Tbsp salt, or to taste ($0.10)\n1.5 cups long grain white rice (uncooked) ($0.93)\n3 green onions ($0.22)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. The night before, add the dry beans to a large bowl with double their volume in water. Allow the beans to soak in the refrigerator overnight.\n2. When you're ready to start cooking, slice the sausage into rounds. Add the cooking oil and sliced sausage to a large pot and cook over medium until the sausage pieces are browned. Remove the cooked sausage with a slotted spoon to a clean bowl. Place the cooked sausage in the refrigerator while you prepare the rest of the dish.\n3. While the sausage is cooking, dice the onion, bell pepper, and celery. Mince the garlic.\n4. After removing the cooked sausage, add the onion, bell pepper, celery, and garlic to the pot. Saut\u00e9 over medium heat, allowing the moisture from the vegetables to help dissolve any browned bits off the bottom of the pot as you stir.\n5. Add the smoked paprika, oregano, thyme, garlic powder, onion powder, cayenne, black pepper, and bay leaves to the pot. Stir and cook for one minute more.\n6. Drain and rinse the soaked beans. Add them to the pot along with 6 cups water and give the pot a brief stir to combine the ingredients.\n7. Place a lid on the pot, turn the heat up to medium-high, and bring it up to a boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to medium-low, and let the pot boil for one hour, stirring occasionally. Replace the lid every time you stir.\n8. After boiling for one hour, the beans should be tender. Begin to smash the beans with the back of a spoon against the side of the pot. Continue smashing the beans and letting the pot simmer without a lid for 30 minutes to thicken the pot.\n9. While the beans are simmering for their final 30 minutes, cook the rice. Add the rice and 3 cups water to a sauce pot. Place a lid on top, turn the heat on to high, and bring it up to a boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to low and let the rice simmer for 15 minutes. After 15 minutes, turn the heat off and let the rice rest for 5 minutes without removing the lid. Fluff the rice with a fork before serving.\n10. Once the red beans have thickened, add the cooked sausage back to the pot along with 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley. Stir to combine. Taste the red beans and add salt to your liking. Start with 1 tsp and add more as needed. I used 1 Tbsp total (3 tsp).\n11. Serve the red beans in a bowl topped with a scoop of rice and a sprinkle of sliced green onions.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Soak beans\n0:13 Drain beans\n0:16 Cook sausage\n0:22 Saut\u00e9 onion, celery, bell peppers, garlic\n0:30 Add seasoning\n0:35 Add soaked beans and water\n0:42 Simmer\n0:46 Smash beans\n0:50 Return sausage to pot\n0:52 Add fresh parsley & salt\n0:58 Serve and enjoy", "uploadDate": "2022-03-06T16:00:02+00:00", "duration": "PT1M8S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/awTM_rrfLKQ/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/awTM_rrfLKQ?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=awTM_rrfLKQ", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 1.5 cups red beans each"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT120M", "totalTime": "PT615M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb. dry red beans ($1.96)", "2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)", "14 oz. Andouille sausage* ($3.47)", "1  yellow onion ($0.70)", "1  green bell pepper ($0.86)", "3  ribs celery ($0.56)", "4 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.20)", "1 tsp dried oregano ($0.10)", "1 tsp dried thyme ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp onion powder ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.03)", "1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.04)", "2  bay leaves ($0.20)", "6 cups water ($0.00)", "1/4 cup chopped parsley ($0.20)", "1 Tbsp salt, or to taste ($0.09)", "1.5 cups long grain white rice, uncooked** ($0.72)", "3  green onions ($0.30)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The night before, add the dry beans to a large bowl with double their volume in water. We made chicken on the side to make it a full meal", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "MJ"}, "datePublished": "2025-12-10"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I\u2019ve made this before and my kids definitely enjoyed it. A funny story--when I moved to Austin, Texas in 1986, the first thing I was assigned to bring to a office potluck was chili. Having grown up in the midwest and lived in the southeast much of my adult life, I immediately researched recipes and made a spectacular pot of Texas Red using round steak in about a 1/2\" dice, and very tender thanks to my pressure cooker--about 4 qts, no tomatoes, no beans, but lots of mild dried chilies and a bottle of beer. Cocoa and cumin are also included. The pot disappeared in almost a flash--at which point I learned from all of my astounded, but pleased, coworkers that they made chili the ordinary American way with tomatoes and beans. In Texas that means pinto beans, or at least it did in Texas in the 80s &amp; 90s. I still make my Texas Red from time to time, but not often--I tend to wait for DIL to do it and invite us over. Pour melted butter and olive oil over the florets, tossing them to coat.**", "name": "Toss", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/loaded-cauliflower-bowls/#wprm-recipe-112513-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the florets on a parchment-lined baking sheet and sprinkle with salt and pepper. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/skillet-pineapple-bbq-chicken/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n 1 Tbsp cooking oil \n6 boneless skinless chicken thighs* (about 2.3 lbs.) \nPinch Salt and pepper \n20 oz. can Pineapple slices in juice \n1/2 cup BBQ sauce \n1 jalape\u00f1o (optional), sliced thinly \n2 green onions, sliced \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Heat a large skillet over medium. Once hot add the cooking oil and swirl to coat the surface. While waiting for the skillet to heat, season both sides of the chicken thighs with a pinch of salt and pepper.\n2. Once the skillet is hot and the oil is shimmering, add the chicken thighs and cook until golden brown on each side and cooked through. Remove the cooked chicken to a clean plate.\n3. While the chicken is cooking, drain and reserve the juice from the canned pineapple slices.\n4. After removing the chicken from the skillet, turn the heat down to low and add about 1/2 cup of the reserved pineapple juice. Stir to dissolve and loosen the browned chicken bits from the bottom of the skillet. Once everything has been loosened from the skillet, add the BBQ sauce and stir until a thick sauce forms. Taste the sauce and add salt if needed. If your sauce gets too thick, simply add another splash of the reserved pineapple juice.\n5. Add the cooked chicken thighs and pineapple slices to the skillet, dredging both sides in the pineapple BBQ sauce.  Spoon any excess sauce over the chicken.\n6. Adjust your oven's rack so that the skillet will be about 6 inches from the broiler unit and turn the broiler on to high. Transfer the skillet to the oven and broil for about 5 minutes, or just until the BBQ sauce caramelizes on the edges of the chicken and pineapple. If you don't have an oven safe skillet** you can transfer the chicken, pineapple, and ALL of the sauce to a casserole dish for broiling, or skip the broiling step and enjoy as is.\n7. After broiling, sprinkle the sliced jalape\u00f1o and green onion over top, and then serve.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-06-22T17:33:31+00:00", "duration": "PT1M2S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/nJlKlRai8Sw/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/nJlKlRai8Sw?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nJlKlRai8Sw", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)", "6  boneless skinless chicken thighs (about 2.3 lbs., $8.00*)", "20 oz. can pineapple slices ( in juice, $1.68)", "1/2 cup BBQ sauce ($0.68)", "1  jalape\u00f1o ( (optional) sliced thinly, $0.33)", "2  green onions (sliced, $0.20)", "pinch  salt ($0.02)", "pinch  freshly cracked black pepper ($0.03)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat a large skillet over medium. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/baked-barley-mushrooms/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n2 cloves garlic ($0.16)\n8 oz. mushrooms ($1.49)\n4 Tbsp butter ($0.40)\n1 cup pearled barley ($0.57)\n2 cups vegetable broth ($0.26)\n1/2 tsp dried thyme ($0.05)\n1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n1 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley (optional) ($0.10)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS \n1. Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Mince the garlic and slice the mushrooms\n2. Add the garlic, mushrooms, and butter to a Dutch oven. Saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the mushrooms have softened.\n3. Add the barley, vegetable broth, thyme and freshly cracked pepper to the dutch oven. Stir to combine, place the lid on top, and transfer to the oven. Bake the barley for one hour.\n4. After baking for one hour, stir the barley to fluff it up. Give the barley a taste and adjust the salt or pepper to your liking. Top with chopped fresh parsley just before serving.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIME STAMPS \n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Prep Garlic and Mushrooms\n0:12 Saut\u00e9 Garlic and Mushrooms\n0:20 Add Barley, Broth, and Herbs\n0:29 Bake\n0:32 Fluff and Season\n0:40 Serve and Enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2022-11-20T15:27:17+00:00", "duration": "PT50S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/KPwyWHtiwUo/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/KPwyWHtiwUo?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPwyWHtiwUo", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 1 cup each"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT65M", "totalTime": "PT70M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "8 oz. mushrooms ($1.49)", "4 Tbsp butter ($0.40)", "1 cup pearled barley ($0.57)", "2 cups vegetable broth ($0.26)", "1/2 tsp dried thyme ($0.05)", "1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)", "1 Tbsp chopped fresh parsley (optional) ($0.10)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Making great food is my passion, my purpose, and my favorite thing to share with others.", "sameAs": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/about/", "https://www.facebook.com/budgetbytes1", "https://x.com/Budget_Bytes"], "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/author/beth/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Spicy Coconut Vegetable Stir Fry", "author": {"@id": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/#/schema/person/de533a4dad507aefcf8ea04e131701f9"}, "description": "This rich and spicy coconut vegetable stir fry is adaptable to whatever vegetables are lingering in your fridge, making it a great sweep the kitchen recipe!", "datePublished": "2018-12-06T16:50:03+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Spicy-Coconut-Vegetable-Stir-Fry-over-rice.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Spicy-Coconut-Vegetable-Stir-Fry-over-rice-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Spicy-Coconut-Vegetable-Stir-Fry-over-rice-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Spicy-Coconut-Vegetable-Stir-Fry-over-rice-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Spicy Coconut Vegetable Stir Fry", "description": "This rich and spicy coconut vegetable stir fry is adaptable to whatever vegetables are lingering in your fridge, making it a great sweep the kitchen recipe! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/spicy-coconut-vegetable-stir-fry/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\nSPICY COCONUT SAUCE\n1 13.5 oz can full-fat coconut milk\n1/4 cup natural style peanut butter\n2 Tbsp sriracha \n1 tsp brown sugar \n1 Tbsp soy sauce\n2 Tbsp lime juice (about one lime) \n1 clove garlic, minced \n1 tsp grated fresh ginger \n\nSTIR FRY\n4-6 cups mixed vegetables \n1 Tbsp high heat cooking oil of choice \n\nOPTIONAL FOR SERVING\n4 cups cooked rice (or 8oz. noodles) \n1/4 cup chopped peanuts \n1/4 cup chopped cilantro\n1 lime (cut into wedges) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. In a medium bowl, whisk together the coconut milk, peanut butter, sriracha, brown sugar, soy sauce, lime juice, minced garlic, and grated ginger. If needed, gently heat the sauce in the microwave or in a sauce pot to help the peanut butter melt into the coconut milk. Taste the sauce and adjust the heat (sriracha), salt (soy sauce), sweetness (brown sugar), or tartness (lime juice) to your liking.\n2. Chop your vegetables, if not pre-chopped. Heat the cooking oil in a large skillet over medium high heat. Once hot, add the vegetables to the skillet in order of hardest to softest to allow harder vegetables, like carrots, more time to cook and to avoid over cooking softer vegetables. Stir fry the vegetables only for about 1-2 minutes, or just until they begin to soften on the edges because they will cook further once the sauce is added. If using a tender green, like spinach, wait to add it to the skillet until after the sauce has been added.\n3. Pour the prepared spicy coconut sauce over the vegetables, stir to combine, and allow the sauce to heat through (about 2 minutes). If you are using a tender green, like spinach, stir it into the hot sauce and stir just until it has wilted.\n4. To serve, spoon the vegetables and sauce over a bowl of hot rice, or add pre-cooked noodles to the skillet and toss with the vegetables and sauce until combined. Top with chopped peanuts, cilantro, and serve with a wedge of lime to squeeze over top.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-02-07T20:11:44+00:00", "duration": "PT59S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ocxXK5gFG-0/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/ocxXK5gFG-0?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ocxXK5gFG-0", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 13.5oz. can full-fat coconut milk ($1.79)", "1/4 cup natural style peanut butter ($0.28)", "2 Tbsp sriracha ($0.18)", "1 tsp brown sugar ($0.01)", "1 Tbsp soy sauce ($0.06)", "2 Tbsp lime juice (about one lime) ($0.22)", "1 clove garlic, minced ($0.08)", "1 tsp grated fresh ginger ($0.10)", "4-6 cups mixed vegetables ($1.93)", "1 Tbsp high heat cooking oil of choice ($0.04)", "4 cups cooked rice (or 8oz. noodles) ($0.70)", "1/4 cup chopped peanuts ($0.12)", "1/4 cup chopped cilantro ($0.22)", "1  lime (cut into wedges) ($0.22)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the coconut milk, peanut butter, sriracha, brown sugar, soy sauce, lime juice, minced garlic, and grated ginger. Excellent recipe!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sho Sho"}, "datePublished": "2023-10-12"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "There are plenty of alternatives to sriracha, depending on which of its ingredients are your problem. It's an American product based on Thai sauces and primarily composed of red jalapenos, so I would stay away from Mexican hot sauces, too. Tabasco uses completely different peppers, as does my heat ingredient of choice for this delicious recipe. I used Thai Kitchen brand Thai red curry paste--a tiny 4 oz jar. It's made in Thailand, and contains red chili (not jalapenos), garlic, lemon grass, galangal (similar to ginger), salt, onion, kafir lime. There are no chemical preservatives listed. I bought this at my local supermarket. It costs a bit more than sriracha, but is still inexpensive.\r\n\r\nMy preferred Thai curry pastes are Maesri and Mai Ploy brands which come in 4 oz cans and which I have to mail order. Red chili and Panang curries are about the same thing. If you leave out sriracha or another chili based product, your recipe will lack not only flavor and heat, but the lovely pink color.\r\n\r\nOne commenter suggested using chili paste with garlic--there are both Chinese and Thai varieties, both very good, but my preference is Chinese style.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Janet"}, "datePublished": "2023-04-01"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "2"}, "reviewBody": "Big fan here but this one didn't do it for me. \u00a0I'm allergic to Sirachi so maybe that would have made it but this was pretty bland and meh and I love peanut sauce.. \u00a0I wouldn't make this again or recommend it. \u00a0Other great Stir fries on here..", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Elizabeth"}, "datePublished": "2022-05-13"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "So easy, so flexible, so tasty, so healthy!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Susan"}, "datePublished": "2022-04-08"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This is my favorite Budget Bytes recipe, which is really saying something because so many of my go-to dinners are from here. This scratches the takeout itch but is so much more cost-effective and I love that it is customizable. It makes a generous quantity, reheats nicely, and is incredibly flexible. \r\n\r\nTonight, I doubled the sauce so that the rice would be extra saucy. I added about 1/4 cup of additional peanut butter to make it nice and peanutty. I had the natural kind of peanut butter on hand tonight instead of the usual Jif or whatever, and I think the slightly coarser texture was really good in the sauce. I forgot to get a lime, but subbed the juice of one Meyer lemon and it added nice acidity. I was feeling fancy tonight, so I also stir fried some pork loin and added that, although I usually make this vegan and love it that way too. This is fantastic with all kinds of veggies; it's one of those recipes that you can buy specific things for, or just clean out the fridge! Tonight, I used carrots, half a head of purple cabbage, frozen broccoli crowns, and a couple big handfuls of fresh spinach leaves. I served over jasmine rice and topped each portion with crushed peanuts. It was colorful, super filling, and made a ton! I'm looking forward to eating the leftovers for lunch tomorrow. \r\n\r\nI recommend this recipe to everyone I know. Thanks for all your hard work, Beth! It gives it a lil extra something and my family always wants me to bring this side dish for the holidays.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Dayna"}, "datePublished": "2025-01-03"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Delicious. I have a few other versions of this in my repertoire--how can an Iowa farm girl resist any corn recipe! This one is easiest and wonderful. \r\n\r\nThe women in my father's family always cooked corn in milk. My mother didn't, nor do I typically do so, but corn has a great affinity for recipes that include dairy. Everyone I knew back in those days before microwaves and recipes for grilled and roasted veggies, boiled corn, either on the ear or cut kernels, with a little dab of sugar and saved the salt until it was cooked. I learned to cook other sweet veggies such as fresh green peas, baby limas, and carrots with a touch of sugar instead of salt. It keeps them tender and enhances natural sweetness. I use maybe 1/4 tsp per 1/2 cup of cooking water, which is enough liquid for 2 c of veggies and is likely to be nearly all absorbed while cooking. Green vegetables, other than peas, need salted water both for flavor and to preserve the color.\r\n\r\nKeep these terrific side dish recipes coming!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "janmaus"}, "datePublished": "2024-11-13"}], "recipeCategory": ["Side Dish"], "recipeCuisine": ["American"], "keywords": "creamed corn", "nutrition": {"@type": "NutritionInformation", "servingSize": "1 serving (\u00bd a cup)", "calories": "137 kcal", "carbohydrateContent": "4 g", "proteinContent": "3 g", "fatContent": "12 g", "sodiumContent": "320 mg", "fiberContent": "0.1 g"}, "@id": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/creamed-corn/#recipe", "isPartOf": {"@id": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/creamed-corn/#article"}, "mainEntityOfPage": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/creamed-corn/"}]}]
